sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying rectangular loop
message_1: A rectangular loop with sides of length 0.2 m and 0.3 m carries a current of 5 A. Calculate the magnitude and direction of the magnetic field at the center of the loop. Assume the loop is positioned in vacuum.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at the center of the rectangular loop, we can use the Biot-Savart law. However, since the loop has a rectangular shape, we can simplify the calculation by considering the contributions of the magnetic field from each side of the rectangle separately and then summing them up.

Let's consider the magnetic field contributions from the two longer sides (0.3 m) first. Since they are equal in length and carry the same current, their magnetic field contributions at the center will be equal in magnitude but opposite in direction. Therefore, they will cancel each other out.

Now, let's consider the magnetic field contributions from the two shorter sides (0.2 m). They are also equal in length and carry the same current, so their magnetic field contributions at the center will be equal in magnitude and in the same direction. We can calculate the magnetic field from one of these sides using the formula for the magnetic field due to a straight current-carrying wire at a perpendicular distance from the wire:

B = (μ₀ * I) / (2 * π * d)

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current (5 A), and d is the perpendicular distance from the wire to the center of the loop (half of the longer side, 0.15 m).

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 5 A) / (2 * π * 0.15 m)
B = (2 × 10^(-6) T) / 0.15 m
B = 1.33 × 10^(-5) T

Since there are two shorter sides contributing to the magnetic field, we need to double the result:

Total B = 2 * 1.33 × 10^(-5) T = 2.67 × 10^(-5) T

The direction of the magnetic field will be perpendicular to the plane of the loop and can be determined using the right-hand rule. If you point your thumb in the direction of the current and curl your fingers, the direction of the magnetic field will follow the curl of your fingers. In this case, the magnetic field will be pointing either into or out of the plane of the loop, depending on the direction of the current.

So, the magnitude of the magnetic field at the center of the rectangular loop is 2.67 × 10^(-5) T, and the direction is perpendicular to the plane of the loop.
